page.title: 16ECOLOGY(3)
page.content: The underlying soil is alkaline. Most of the land is ploughed or grazed by sheep most of the wild flowers occur on road margins or close to stone walls and hedgerows. The first flowers to emerge in March are daisies and celandines. At the top of Dyer's lane grows a clump of wild daffodils and the tiny sweet violet.On warm days the brimstone butterfly appears. A count in April gives these flowers as well:- shepherd's cress, coltsfoot,red deadnettle, dandelion, celandine, chickweed. The willows glow against the dark leafless woods and inside the anemone blooms.In May the roadside bursts into blossom with the cow parsley.June brings out the campion red early then white.Ladies bedstraw and harebells grow on Dover's Hill. We counted 50 varieties of wild flowers within a kilometre of school in July.
